overview_of_class: This course examines the theory underlying the construction of a financial assets portfolio with the objective of maximizing expected return for a specified tolerable level of risk. Topics covered include, among others, risk aversion and utility functions; diversification; theMarkowitz Mean-Variance Portfolio Theory; the Black-Litterman variation of this model; the Capital Asset Pricing Model; index models; multifactor models of risk and return, including the Arbitrage Pricing Theory Model; the efficient market hypothesis; and behavioral finance. Although some of these topics are covered briefly in FINANCE 202, the focus in this course is on a more in-depth analysis of the underlying assumptions of these models.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: FINANCE 202 or its equivalent. Highly motivated students may be able to handle this course material while simultaneously taking FINANCE 202.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
The Markowitz Mean-Variance Portfolio Theory -its implications and underlying assumptions.
The Black-Litterman modification of the Markowitz model and how it compensates for the weaknesses of that model.
The CAPM Model and its underlying assumptions.
Strengths and weaknesses of various proxies to the Market Portfolio.
The basic approach and underlying assumptions to the Index Model.
The Arbitrage Pricing Theory Model and other Multi-Factor Pricing Models
The Efficient Market Hypothesis -implications and critiques.
Behavioral Finance's critiques of the assumptions underlying these models. Prospect Theory. Implications for the lay investor.
